title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for TWO correct identifications
descriptions: The response demonstrates one or neither of the following.
The response correctly identifies the following two types of data used to calculate the rate of natural increase.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe what the total fertility rate represents.

· The total fertility rate measures how many children, on average, a woman can expect to have in her lifetime.

The response correctly describes what the total fertility rate represents as follows.

· The total fertility rate measures how many children, on average, a woman can expect to have in her lifetime.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description.
descriptions: The response does not correctly describe how to calculate the doubling time of India’s population, using any one of the following methods.
The response correctly describes how to calculate the doubling time of India’s population using one of the following methods.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe the ability of China’s population to replace itself over time.

· The table shows that in 2018 China had a total fertility rate of 1.8. For a country’s population to remain stable and replace itself over time, the country must have a total fertility rate of 2.1−2.3 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaigdacqGHsislcaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaiodaaaa@3B57@ . China’s total fertility rate of 1.8 suggests that China’s population will be unable to replace itself over time and that the population will decline.

The response correctly describe the ability of China’s population to replace itself over time.

· The table shows that in 2018 China had a total fertility rate of 1.8. For a country’s population to remain stable and replace itself over time, the country must have a total fertility rate of 2.1−2.3 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaigdacqGHsislcaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaiodaaaa@3B57@ . China’s total fertility rate of 1.8 suggests that China’s population will be unable to replace itself over time and that the population will decline.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct explanation.
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain how China’s population statistics are unusual for a country with an industrializing economy, using any one of the following.
The response correctly explains how China’s population statistics are unusual for a country with an industrializing economy, using any one of the following.
